newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee climbs back after March hits new low.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee climbs back after March hits new low.

text.p: London's robusta coffee contract crumbled to a new life low of $1,229 a tonne on Thursday as market players dumped long positions following a sharp speculator sell-off in the arabicas market, traders said.
"New York sold off violently which brought in a bit of long liquidation and a few spec sellers. It is all inspired by arabicas...it's just spilled over into London," said one.
"We've made a new low on the movement and the market is in a lot of trouble," he said.
But March then found support at the lows at clawed its way higher to close at $1,234, down $26 on the day.

Traders continued to monitor the fortunes of the May/July spread after Wednesday's surprise Exchange announcement on the validity of grading certificates following its previous grading announcement in March.
May/July closed at a $10 discount after fluctuating in a choppy session. January was down $10 at $1,297 and total volume reached 7,984 lots.
New coffee grading criteria now apply to next year's July contract and subsequent delivery months, meaning that May coffee will have to be regraded.
"Anyone who picks up coffee there is going to have to regrade it, they're going to have the expense and aggravation of that," the trader said. --Jeremy Smith, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8064
